Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Control of Partially Observable Wireless Networks: Fundamental Limits, Optimal Algorithms and Practical Implementation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
State dependent resource allocation is critical for improving the network efficiency. Over the past two decades, remarkable progress has been made on the design of wireless networks with maximum throughput and low latency by using state dependent resource allocation algorithms. However, most of these works assume the network is fully observable and the network state information is perfectly known. This assumption is becoming increasingly questionable because of the multi-carrier technology, which makes it extremely expensive to obtain the complete network state information, and transmission delays and measurement errors, which make it impossible to know the exact network state. With wireless networks become pervasive in our daily life, new theories and algorithms are needed for partially observable wireless networks.

In this project, the PI models a partially observable wireless network as a partially observable Markov process, and then applies the framework of Markov decision processes (MDP). While important structure properties may be discovered using the MDP framework, finding optimal solutions in general is an NP-hard problem. To overcome this difficulty, this project uses drift-based competitive analysis and drift-based large-deviations analysis for quantifying fundamental limits and deriving optimal or near optimal algorithms. The project is expected to lead to breakthroughs in managing partially observable wireless networks. Fundamental limits of partially observable wireless networks, novel resource allocation algorithms with provable throughput and latency guarantees, and implementations on a real-world test bed will have a significant impact on the design and implementation of future wireless networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
State dependent resource allocation is imperative for high performance wireless networks. Over the past two decades, remarkable progress has been made on the design of high throughput, low latency wireless networks assuming the network is fully observable. In practice, only incomplete and noisy network state information is available. During the course of this project, we studied the fundamental limits and high-performance algorithm design of partially observable wireless networks. We quantified the fundamental limits of partially observable wireless networks for supporting packets with hard deadlines, both in single-hope and multi-hop wireless networks. We established the multi-dimensional tradeoffs between speedup, scheduling policies, transmit power, and packet delivery ratio. For example, we quantified the throughput and quality-of-service critical speedup requirements for a number of different low-complexity scheduling algorithms that can be easily implemented in practice. We have also studied device-to-device (D2D) communication for 5G, and proposed a new pairwise SIR-based random sequential scheduling algorithm. It is a low complexity, greedy algorithm that only requires local network state information, and achieves significant performance improvement compared with existing algorithms. We have also developed high performance resource allocation algorithm to support end-to-end hard deadlines in multi-hop wireless networks, a well-known open problem in wireless networks. We introduced the concepts of virtual links and routes to incorporate end-to-end deadline constraints into routing. We further developed a novel virtual queue architecture based on local information to guide the spatial-temporal routing which specifies where and when a packet should be routed.

The project informed and educated both students and the broader society with curriculum development on courses on wireless networks and outreach.  The results developed under this project have been included in the textbook co-author by the PI. The textbook has been used as a textbook or reference book of graduate courses on communication networks at a number of universities. The project also played a role in the integration of under-represented groups to the scientific community.
